content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

After considering the payoff structure, I will choose strategy B{B} for this game, primarily because it is less risky. In this game, there are two possible strategies: R and B. If both players pick R, we each earn 45$, which is the highest reward in one round. However, if both of us deviate from the same strategy (one picks R while the other picks B), the player who picked R gets nothing and the other gets a higher payoff (42$).

Considering that I don't know what my opponent will do, it is better to choose B since the worst-case scenario is getting 12$ per round. If I had chosen R and my opponent had chosen B instead, I would have gotten nothing in every single round of the game, which spans 75 rounds. That's a loss of 75 * 45 = $3375, while choosing B results in a guaranteed payout of at least 12$ per round, totaling $900 over the course of the game.

Another aspect to consider is the number of rounds (75) in this game. Over such a large number of rounds, it's more likely that my opponent and I will end up choosing the same strategy eventually, which would result in earning 45$ per round. This is because if we alternate our choices (R, B, R, B, ...), we still get 12$ per round, while if we both choose the same option, we get a higher payoff.

In summary, choosing strategy B{B} minimizes my risk and guarantees a consistent payout of at least 12$ per round. Additionally, there's a chance that I might end up with a higher payoff if my opponent and I eventually choose the same strategy (R or B) repeatedly.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Based on my previous reasoning, I will continue choosing strategy B{B} in this game. The fact that my opponent chose R in the first round did not change my decision to choose B for the rest of the game, as I aimed to minimize my risk and secure consistent payouts of at least 12$ per round. I understand that there is a chance that if we alternate our choices (R, B, R, B, ...), we could end up getting 0$ in every round, but I am more focused on the guaranteed income from choosing strategy B. So, I will stick with my choice of B for this game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

If we both have chosen strategy B{B} in the previous rounds, and our payoffs are both 12$, I will continue choosing strategy B for the next round. Since we are both earning a consistent income of 12$ per round by choosing B, there is no incentive to switch strategies at this point.

If we keep alternating our choices (B, R, B, R, ...), we would still get 12$ per round since the payoff for picking B when the opponent picks R is 12$. However, if we both choose the same strategy (R or B) repeatedly, we could earn a higher payoff of 45$ per round. Nevertheless, with this approach, we are guaranteed to get at least 12$ per round, which I believe is beneficial for the entire duration of the game.

Therefore, I will stick with my choice of strategy B{B} for the next round and continue earning a consistent payout of 12$ per round.

Since my previous choice of B resulted in a payoff of 42$ while my opponent got 0$, I will change my strategy for the next round. In this case, if I stick with choosing B, there's a high probability that I will continue earning 0$ per round because my opponent is likely to pick R again. To maximize my payoff, I should switch strategies and choose R{R} for the next round.

If I were to stick with my previous choice of B, I would be taking on unnecessary risk since there's a high chance of earning 0$ per round in the future, which goes against my goal of maximizing payoffs. Choosing strategy R will allow me to get a higher payoff in this round (since my opponent chose R previously) and potentially earn more in the future by alternating our choices (R, B, R, B, ...).

Therefore, I will switch my strategy to R{R} for the next round.
